title: Variable atmosChem.wetno3.tavg-al-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.wetno3)
Comment: This is the loss rate of nitrate aerosol from the atmosphere due to wet deposition

title: Variable atmosChem.wetnh4.tavg-u-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.wetnh4)
Comment: Surface deposition rate of ammonium (NH4) due to wet processes

title: Variable atmosChem.wetnh3.tavg-u-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.wetnh3)
Comment: Surface deposition rate of ammonia (NH3) due to wet processes

title: Variable atmosChem.wethno3.tavg-al-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.wethno3)
Comment: This is the loss rate of nitric acid (HNO3) from the atmosphere due to wet deposition

title: Variable atmosChem.tropo3ste.tavg-al-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.tropo3ste)
Comment: Ozone tracer intended to map out strat-trop exchange (STE) of ozone in the troposphere. It represents the ozone volume mixing ratio in the troposphere that is considered to be stratospheric in origin. It should be consistent with the definition of tropopause used to calculate the pressure of the tropopause (ptp). It should have zero values in the stratosphere and non-zero positive values in the troposphere.
Long name: Tropospheric ozone volume mixing ratio due to stratosphere-troposphere exchange (STE)

title: Variable atmosChem.tropdo3chm.tavg-al-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.tropdo3chm)
Comment: This is the net chemical tendency of ozone in the troposphere. The distinction between the stratosphere and troposphere should be consistent with the definition of the tropopause used in the calculation of the tropopause pressure (ptp). It should have zero values in the stratosphere.
Long name: Net Chemistry Tendency of O3 in troposphere

title: Variable atmosChem.tropch4lossoh.tavg-al-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.tropch4lossoh)
Comment: This is the loss rate of tropospheric methane due to reaction with the hydroxy (OH) radical. The distinction between stratosphere and troposphere should be consistent with the tropopause used to calculate the pressure of the tropopause (ptp). It should have zero values in the stratosphere.
Long name: Tropospheric loss of methane by OH

title: Variable atmosChem.tropch4loss.tavg-al-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.tropch4loss)
Comment: This is the loss rate of tropospheric methane by all chemical destruction. The distinction between stratosphere and troposphere should be consistent with the tropopause used in the calculation of the tropopause pressure (ptp). It should have zero values in the stratosphere.
Long name: Loss of Tropospheric Methane by all chemical destruction

title: Variable atmosChem.stratch4loss.tavg-al-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.stratch4loss)
Comment: This is the loss rate of stratospheric methane by all chemical destruction. The distinction between the stratosphere and troposphere should be consistent with the tropopause as used in the calculation of the tropopause pressure (ptp). It should have zero values in the troposphere.
Long name: Loss of Stratospheric Methane by all chemical destruction

title: Variable atmosChem.rsuto3ref.tavg-u-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.rsuto3ref)
Comment: This is top-of-atmosphere outgoing shortwave flux for all-sky conditions from a diagnostic call to the radiation scheme, using a reference ozone field
Long name: TOA shortwave flux assuming reference ozone field

title: Variable atmosChem.rsutcso3ref.tavg-u-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.rsutcso3ref)
Comment: This represents the top-of-atmosphere outgoing shortwave radiative flux assuming clear-sky conditions when a reference ozone field is used in a diagnostic call to the radiation scheme
Long name: TOA shortwave flux assuming clear sky and reference ozone

title: Variable atmosChem.rsutcsch4ref.tavg-u-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.rsutcsch4ref)
Comment: This is the outgoing shortwave flux at the top-of-atmosphere for clear-sky conditions from a diagnostic call to the radiation scheme with a reference methane field
Long name: TOA outgoing shortwave flux assuming clear-sky and reference methane field

title: Variable atmosChem.rsutch4ref.tavg-u-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.rsutch4ref)
Comment: This is the outgoing shortwave flux at the top-of-atmosphere for all-sky conditions from a diagnostic call to the radiation scheme with a reference methane field
Long name: TOA outgoing shortwave flux assuming reference methane

title: Variable atmosChem.rluto3ref.tavg-u-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.rluto3ref)
Comment: This is outgoing longwave flux at the top-of-atmosphere for all-sky conditions from a diagnostic call to the radiation scheme using a reference ozone field

title: Variable atmosChem.rlutcso3ref.tavg-u-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.rlutcso3ref)
Comment: This is the outgoing longwave flux at the top-of-atmosphere for clear-sky conditions from a diagnostic call to the radiation scheme using a reference ozone field
Long name: TOA outgoing longwave flux assuming clear sky and reference ozone field

title: Variable atmosChem.rlutcsch4ref.tavg-u-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.rlutcsch4ref)
Comment: This is the outgoing longwave flux at the top-of-atmosphere for clear-sky conditions from a diagnostic call to the radiation scheme with a reference methane field
Long name: TOA outgoing longwave flux assuming clear sky and reference methane field

title: Variable atmosChem.rlutch4ref.tavg-u-hxy-u.mon.GLB (AERmon.rlutch4ref)
Comment: This is the outgoing longwave flux at the top-of-atmosphere for all-sky conditions from a diagnostic call to the radiation scheme using a reference methane field
Long name: TOA outgoing longwave flux assuming reference methane field

title: Variable atmosChem.o3ref.tclm-al-hxy-u.fx.GLB (AERfx.o3refClim)
Cell methods: area: mean time: mean within years time: mean over years
Comment: This is the ozone mole fraction that is used in a diagnostic call to the model's radiation scheme. It is only applicable when an ozone double call is active in the model.
Long name: Fixed Reference Climatology of Mole Fraction of Ozone in Air
Processing notes: Use this when o3ref has a repeating climatological cycle.

title: Variable atmosChem.o3ref.ti-al-hxy-u.fx.GLB (AERfx.o3ref)
Comment: This is the ozone mole fraction that is used in a diagnostic call to the model's radiation scheme. It is only applicable when an ozone double call is active in the model.
Long name: Fixed Reference Mole Fraction of Ozone in Air
Processing notes: Use this when o3ref has no annual cycle.

title: Variable atmosChem.ch4ref.ti-al-hxy-u.fx.GLB (AERfx.ch4ref)

Long name: Reference mole fraction of methane in air

title: Variable atmosChem.o3.tclm-p19-hxy-air.mon.GLB (Amon.o3Clim)
CMIP6 Differences: "frequency" was "monC"; ; "cell_methods" was "area: mean time: mean within years time: mean over years"; ; "modeling_realm" was "atmos atmosChem";
Cell methods: area: mean where air time: mean within years time: mean over years
Comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.
Processing notes: If O3 does not vary from one year to the next, report 12 months, starting with January. (Note: include all 12 months even if the values do not vary seasonally.) When calling CMOR, identify this variable as tro3Clim, not tro3. If the O3 varies from one year to the next, then report instead the field described in the previous table entry. Are these the preferred units or should it be a unitless fraction? Should this field be reported instead on model levels? Or should we also require either the vertically integrated mole fraction (or mass?) of this species or the vertically integrated globally averaged mole fraction (or mass?)? CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Cell Methods - CMIP6:area: mean time: mean within years time: mean over years CMIP7:area: mean where air time: mean within years time: mean over years,

title: Variable atmosChem.o3.tavg-p19-hxy-air.mon.GLB (Amon.o3)
labels: mon atmosChem CMIP6 UKESM1 HadGEM3-GC31 approved
Comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.
Processing notes: If this does not change over time (except possibly to vary identically over each annual cycle), report instead the variable described in the next table entry. Are these the preferred units or should it be a unitless fraction? Should this field be reported instead on model levels? Or should we also require either the vertically integrated mole fraction (or mass?) of this species or the vertically integrated globally averaged mole fraction (or mass?)? CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Cell Methods - CMIP6:time: mean CMIP7:area: time: mean where air,

title: Variable atmosChem.n2o.tclm-u-hm-u.mon.GLB (Amon.n2oglobalClim)
CMIP6 Differences: "frequency" was "monC"; ; "cell_methods" was "area: mean time: mean within years time: mean over years"; ; "units" was "1e-09"; ; "modeling_realm" was "atmos atmosChem";
Cell methods: height: area: time: mean (with all samples weighted by the number of moles of air in the sample)
Comment: Global mean Nitrous Oxide (N2O)
Long name: Global Mean Mole Fraction of N2O
Processing notes: Report only for simulations (e.g., prescribed concentration pi-control run), in which the N2O does not vary from one year to the next. Report 12 monthly values, starting with January, even if the values do not vary seasonally. When calling CMOR, identify this variable as ch4globalClim, not ch4global. If N2O is spatially nonuniform, omit this field, but report Global Mean Mole Fraction of N2O (see the table entry before the previous one). Are these the preferred units or should it be a unitless fraction? Should this field be reported instead on model levels? Or should we also require either the vertically integrated mole fraction (or mass?) of this species or the vertically integrated globally averaged mole fraction (or mass?)? CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Units (from Physical Parameter) - CMIP6:1.00E-09 CMIP7:mol mol-1, CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Cell Methods - CMIP6:area: mean time: mean within years time: mean over years CMIP7:height: area: time: mean (with all samples weighted by the number of moles of air in the sample),

title: Variable atmosChem.n2o.tavg-u-hm-u.mon.GLB (Amon.n2oglobal)
labels: mon atmosChem CMIP6 UKESM1 HadGEM3-GC31 approved
CMIP6 Differences: "units" was "1e-09"; ; "modeling_realm" was "atmos atmosChem"; ; "cell_methods" was "area: time: mean";
Cell methods: height: area: time: mean (with all samples weighted by the number of moles of air in the sample)
Comment: Global mean Nitrous Oxide (N2O)
Long name: Global Mean Mole Fraction of N2O
Processing notes: For some simulations (e.g., prescribed concentration pi-control run), this will not vary from one year to the next, and so report instead the variable described in the next table entry. If N2O is spatially nonuniform, omit this field, but report Mole Fraction of N2O (see the table entry before the previous one). Are these the preferred units or should it be a unitless fraction? Should this field be reported instead on model levels? Or should we also require either the vertically integrated mole fraction (or mass?) of this species or the vertically integrated globally averaged mole fraction (or mass?)? CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Cell Methods - CMIP6:area: time: mean CMIP7:height: area: time: mean (with all samples weighted by the number of moles of air in the sample),

Should this field be reported instead on model levels? Or should we also require either the vertically integrated mole fraction (or mass?) of this species or the vertically integrated globally averaged mole fraction (or mass?)? CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Cell Methods - CMIP6:area: mean time: mean within years time: mean over years CMIP7:area: mean where air time: mean within years time: mean over years,

title: Variable atmosChem.hcfc22.tavg-u-hm-u.mon.GLB (Amon.hcfc22global)
CMIP6 Differences: "units" was "1e-12"; ; "modeling_realm" was "atmos atmosChem"; ; "cell_methods" was "area: time: mean";
Cell methods: height: area: time: mean (with all samples weighted by the number of moles of air in the sample)
Comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. The chemical formula for HCFC22 is CHClF2. The IUPAC name for HCFC22 is chloro-difluoro-methane.

Comment: Global Mean Mole Fraction of CH4
Long name: Global Mean Mole Fraction of CH4
Processing notes: Report only for simulations (e.g., prescribed concentration pi-control run), in which the CH4 does not vary from one year to the next. Report 12 monthly values, starting with January, even if the values do not vary seasonally. When calling CMOR, identify this variable as ch4globalClim, not ch4global. If CH4 is spatially nonuniform, omit this field, but report Global Mean Mole Fraction of CH4 (see the table entry before the previous one). Are these the preferred units or should it be a unitless fraction? Should this field be reported instead on model levels? Or should we also require either the vertically integrated mole fraction (or mass?) of this species or the vertically integrated globally averaged mole fraction (or mass?)?
